bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: Sacred Stories 28: The Origin of Horses

p.seg: kîtahtawê ê-mihcêticik ayîsiyiniwak , pêyak okimâw otawâsimisah nistoh , nâpêwak . Once upon a time, in a place where there were many people, a certain chief had three children, sons.
nîso ayâwêwak iskwêwah . Two of them had wives.
osîmimâw ôw oskinîkiw miyosiw . As for the youngest son, this youth was handsome.
êkosi namoy âwiya ayâwêw iskwêwa ; mâka mistahi kitimâkêyimik kahkiyaw ostêsah , wîtimwah ; He, then, had no wife, but both of his elder brothers, as well as his sisters-in-law loved him very much;
tâpiskôc awâsis êkosi pamihâw , osâm êh-kitimâkêyimiht , nisto mîkiwâhpah mâ-mêskoc êkotah êh-pîhtokêt . he was cared for like an own child, so beloved was he, as he went in turn to the three tipis.

êkosi kîtahtawêh , - ostêsimâwa ôh ostêsah mistahi kitimâkêyimik ôhi wîtimwah , - êkwah mitoni êh-oskinîkit , kîtahtawêh êh-pîhtokêt ôh ôstêsah ostêsimâwa wîkiyihk , pôtih pêyakwapiw aw iskwêw . Then at one time his eldest brother's wife was especially fond of him when he had become quite a young man, as once he entered his eldest brother's dwelling, there was that woman alone in the tent.

êkosi ê-wîh-wayawît ,
cêskwa ! itik wîtimwa ; “When, accordingly, he made to go out, “Wait!” his sister-in-law said to him;
mîcisoh , itik . “First eat a bit,” she told him.
êkosi asamik . So she gave him something to eat.
ê-kîsi-mîcisot , ê-wîh-sîkahokot , pasikôw , ê-wîh-wayawît . When he had eaten, she wanted to comb his hair, but he arose to leave the tent.
kiwî-sîkahotih ôma ! itik wîtimwah . “Oh, but I meant to comb your hair, you know!” his sister-in-law said to him.
osâm kipêyakwapin , itêw . “No, for you are alone in the tent,” he told her.
êkosi pasikôw aw iskwêw , iskwâhtêmihk êh-nîpawit , êh-kipiskawât wîtimwa . At that the woman rose to her feet and stood in the doorway, blocking the passage for her brother-in-law.

ômis îtêw :
nîtim , k-ôh-kitimâkêyimitân , ê-wîh-wîhtamâtân , kit-ôh-owîcimosimiyin , itêw ,
ayôwâkês ka-kitimâkêyimitin , itêw . she said to him, “Brother-in-law, fond as I have been of you from the beginning, what I want to tell you is, [no translation]
namoya ! itwêw aw oskinîkiw ; [no translation]

seg.q: osâm tâpiskôc nikâwiy nitêyihtên tahtoh k-ôwîtimoyân .
seg.gloss: [no translation]

p.seg: nisâkwêyimon , itêw wîtimwah ; [no translation]

seg.gloss: [no translation]

p.seg: êkosi wayawîw aw oskinîkiw . With that the young man went out of the tent.

êkosih ômis îtêyihtam aw îskwêw :
mâskôc wîhtamawâcih ostêsah , ta-kisiwâsiw niwîkimâkan , itêyihtam ; Then the woman thought, “If, likely enough, he tells his brother about this, my husband will be very angry,” she thought;
nicawâc nka-wîhtamawâw niwîkimâkan , itêyihtam ; “I had better tell my husband,” she thought;
nicawâc maywês wîhtamawât ostêsah , niya nka-wîhtamawâw , itêyihtam . “Before he tells his brother, I had better tell him myself,” she thought.

êh-pîhtokêyit owîkimâkana , ômis îtêw :
niwîkimâkan , namoya êkos ê-kîh-itêyihtamân , kisîm k-ôh-kitimâkêyimak . When her husband came into the tent, she told him thus: “My husband, it was not in this way that I meant it, when from the first I showed affection to your younger brother. kîh with negative?
anohc êh-pîhtokêt , nkakwêcimik ta-nôcîhkawit , itêw ; [no translation] she told him,

seg.gloss: “I was greatly surprised when he spoke in this way to me; that is why I am telling you of it.

p.seg: êkosi namoya êkwah nika-kîh-kitimâkêyimâw kisîm , itêw . And so now I shall no longer be able to feel any fondness for your younger brother,” she told him.
sêmâk pakwâtam awa nâpêw . At once that man was distressed.

namoya êkosi ê-kîh-têyihtamân ,
kakwê-kitimâkêyim nisîm , k-ôh-ititân mâna , itêw . “It was not in this way that I meant it, when I would say to you, ‘Try to be fond of my young brother’,” he told her.
êkosi aw ôskinîkiw nêpêwisiw ê-kîh-itikot wîtimwa . Now the young man was embarrassed by what his sister-in-law had said to him.
namoya wîh-ay-itohtêw . He did not feel like going there any more.

tâpwê êtokê êkos êh-itêyihtahk nisîm , êkwah êkâ kâ-pîhtokêt , itêyihtam aw ôstêsimâw . It really seems that my young brother did intend something like that, seeing that he does not come to my tent any more,” thought that eldest brother.
mâka kisiwâsiw ôma k-êtikot owîkimâkana . He was very angry at what his wife had told him.

kîtahtawê wîhkâc êh-itohtêt aw ôskinîkiw , ê-wîh-pîhtokêt , wâpamik ostêsah . Then at one time, when the young man, after a long interval, did go there, as he was about to step into the tent, his eldest brother saw him.

môhkomân otinam ,
nika-nipahâw nisîm , êh-itêyihtahk . He seized a knife, thinking, “I shall kill my young brother.”
ê-pê-pîhtokêyit , ê-wîh-tahkamât , asêpayihôw aw oskinîkiw . As the latter was coming in, and he made to stab him, the young man threw himself back.
têpiyâhk apisîs pikwâhok . He managed to run the knife into him a little ways.
namoya mitoni pikwatayêhok . He stabbed him in the abdomen, not deeply.
êkos îsi wayawiyâmôw aw oskinîkiw , êh-ma-mawimoyit wîtimwah ôhi kâ-misimikot . The youth fled out of the tent; his sister-in-law who had slandered him kept crying out the while.
kotakak iskwêwak êh-wayawîcik môskîstawêwak ôhi nâpêwa , êh-nawaswâtâyit osîmiyiwa . Other women came out of their tipis and ran at the man who was pursuing his young brother.
nawatinâw awa nâpêw , ê-miciminiht . The man was seized and held.
êkosi pôyôw . So he gave up his intent.
kîwêhtahâw . He was taken home.
ê-pîhtokêt wîkiwâhk , kotakak nâpêwak pîhtokêwak , êh-kitahamâht . When he went into his tipi, other men came in to admonish him.

seg.gloss: “Why has he done thus to his younger brother, when he is known to be fond of him?”

p.seg:
âcimôw :
êh-kakwêcimât wîtimwah êh-wîh-ôwîcimosit , êyak ôhci k-ôh-tôtawak , itêw . He told his story: [no translation] is why I have done this to him,” he told them.
êkosi aw ôskinîkiw ôhtâwiyah wîkiyihk êkotê pîhtokahâw , êh-nanâtawihiht . Then the young man was brought into his father's dwelling and given medical treatment.

piyisk kinwêsk ayâw , ê-wîsakêyihtahk , ôhôsîmimâwa ostêsah êh-pamihikot êkwah owîtimwah . It turned out that he stayed a long time, suffering pain, and nursed by the younger of his elder brothers, and by his sisters-in-law. h-epenthesis after o prefix
nîso ayâwêyiwa iskwêwah . This brother had two wives.

êwakonik mistahi pakwâtamwak êh-tôtâmiht ôh ôskinîkiwa wîtimowâwa , osâm tâpiskôc otawâsimisiwâwa êy-isi-kitimâkêyimâcik ôhi . They were very much distressed at what had been done to the youth, their brother-in-law, for they loved him like an own child.
mâskôc ahpôh ta-nipiw , itêyihtâkosiw aw oskinîkiw . “Likely enough he will die,” was the general thought concerning that young man.
êh-âtah-nanâtawihiht , piyisk kinwêsk âhkosiw . In spite of the curative treatment give him, for a long time, in the outcome, he was ill.

piyisk kîwêhtahêw awa osîma wîkiwâhk , ê-wîh-pamihât ,
osâm êh-kwatakihtât nôhtâwiy mîna nikâwiy , êh-pamihâcik nisîma , êh-itêyihtahk ; At last the man took his young brother to his own tent, to nurse him, thinking, “It is too much of a strain for my father and mother to nurse my young brother;
mâka êkotê wêtinahk nka-pamihânân , êy-itêyihtahk . over here we can nurse him undisturbed.”
tâpwê pamihêwak osîma . Accordingly, they nursed his young brother.
awa kâ-kîh-tahkamât osîma nama wîhkâc nitawâpamêw , mîn owîkimâkana . The man who had stabbed his brother never came to see him, nor did his wife.
napâwihk kaskêyihtam , êh-nôhtê-wâpamât aw iskwêw kâ-kîh-misimât wîtimwah . Now that it was too late, the woman who had slandered her brother-in-law was sorry and wanted to see him.

nik-êtohtân , êtâcih owîkimâkana , êkos êh-pakamahokot , êh-kâhkwêyihtahk awa , k-ôh-tôtawât osîmah . But whenever she said to her husband, “Let me go there,” he would beat her, for he was jealous, and even for that had done thus to his brother.
piyisk ati-miyw-âyâw aw oskinîkiw . At last the young man was on the way to recovery.

seg.gloss: “Surely, when I get well, my brother will go even so far as to kill me.
If I get well, I shall go away from here.

p.seg: kiyâm pikw îtê wî-misi-wanâtisiyâni , itêyihtam aw oskinîkiw , êh-ati-miyw-âyât . What matter if somewhere or other I go to my destruction?” thought the youth as he got better.

iyikohk êkwah êh-miyw-âyât , mâka namoya wîhkâc nipâyiwa ôhô wîtimwah êkwah ostêsah , mâ-mîskoc êh-kanawêyimikot , têpiskâki êkâyah êh-nipâyit . But when he became well, those sisters-in-law of his and his brother never slept, but took turns in attending to him and not sleeping of nights.

kîtahtawê ôhi osîmimâwa wîtimwah , ê-wîh-wâpaniyik , êkâ êh-na-nipâyit , kiskêyimêw ê-nôhtêhkwasiyit . Once, when the younger of his sisters-in-law was watching, toward dawn, he perceived that she was sleepy.

ômis îtêw :
nîtim ! He said to her, “Sister-in-law!”

seg.gloss: “What is it?”

seg.q: mahtih pahkêkinos pêtâh êkwah astis êkwah oskâcihk .
seg.gloss: “Please give me a small piece of leather and a sinew and an awl.”

p.seg: tanis ê-wîh-tôtaman ? itik . “What do you want to do?” she asked him.
nimaskisin êh-pîkopayik , ê-wîh-mîsahamân , itêw . “It is my moccasin which is torn that I want to mend,” he told her.

seg.gloss: “Take it off and give it to me;
let me sew it.
You are never to do your own sewing, even when you are well;

p.seg: wâwîs ciy êkwah ka-pamihison , âyimâc êh-pimâtisiyan ? itêw ; do you suppose you will be allowed to do your work now that you are barely alive?” she asked him;
misawâc apisîs ôma , itêw . “In any case, this is a little thing,” she told him.
mâka mistahi nôhtêhkwasiw aw osiknîkiskwêw . But the woman was very sleepy.
piyisk miyêw ôhih kâ-nâh-ntotamâkot wîtimwah . At last she gave her brother-in-law what he asked of her.
êkwah manisam aw oskinîkiw , êh-oyisahk ôma pahkêkinos . Then the young man cut from it, cut the leather to shape.
kâ-wâpamât wîtimwah êh-nipêyit , kahkiyaw êwakonih otinam ; As soon as he saw that his sister-in-law was asleep, he took all of those things;
opîhtatwânah otinêw . he took his quiver.

êkos îsi êh-wayawît , ê-sipwêhtêt ,
kiyâm nântaw itê nika-misi-wanâtisin . Thus he went out of the tent and away, thinking, “I may as well go to my destruction, it matters not where.
misawâc tahkih nika-pakwâtik nistês , êh-itêyihtahk . In any case my brother will always despise me.”
êkosi pikont îtêh isi sipwêhtêw . So he set out, with no destination.
iyikohk êh-pêkopayit awa nâpêw , namwâc wâpamêw osîmah . When that man woke up, he did not see his young brother.

ôwîkimâkana koskonêw ,
tâniwâ nisîm ? êh-itât . He roused his wives, asking them, “Where is my brother?”

seg.q:
aspin ôma ,
nika-kaskikwâtên nimaskisina , êh-itwêt , êh-âtah-nah-ntotamôwak , êkâ ê-wîh-miyit , piyisk nimiyâw cit-âpacihtât .
seg.gloss: “The last I know was that he said he was going to mend his moccasins; and though I kept asking him to give them to me, he would not do it, until at last I gave him the things he wanted to use.

p.seg: êkos êh-isi-nahisiniyân , êkos êtokê ninipân , êkâ k-ôh-kiskêyimak êh-wayawît , itêw . Then, when I lay down, I must have fallen asleep and not noticed his going out,” the one told him.
kiskêyihtam êh-sipwêhtêyit awa nâpêw osîma . The man knew that his young brother had gone away.

ntawi-wîhtamawêw ôhtâwiya , ta-ntonâmiht osîma , êh-itêyihtahk , ayisk ôhtâwiya êh-okimâwiyit , êh-tipêyihtamiyit ôtênaw . He went and told his father, that his brother might be looked for, for his father was a chief, and had power over the camp.

êkosi wayawîw awa kisêyiniw , êh-wîhtahk ê-wanihâcik okosisah , ta-mâmawô-ntonâmiht , ê-sîhkihkêmot . So the old man went out of his tent and announced that they had lost his won, and ordered a general search for him.
aw oskinîkiw âsay wâhyaw ayâw . By this time the youth was far off.
itah mistah ê-sakâyik , êkotah sêskisiw . Where there was heavy timber, he went into the woods.
mêkwâ-sakâhk êkotah nahapiw . Well into the woods he sat down.

piyisk kawisimôw ,
êkâ nika-miskâkawih ! êh-itêyihtahk . At last he lay down, thinking, “May I not be found!” LB on {nika-miskâkawih}: Preterit with future particle prefixed. This is not inconsistent with the meaning of the preterit: past intent unaccomplished, or past act no longer true; but the combination is not common enough for me to know its value.
êkwah ôki ayîsiyiniwak misiwê ntonikêwak . Those people searched everywhere.
kiyikâw sakâhk êh-ntonâht , nama miskawâw . He was sought here and there in the woods, but not found.
piyisk tipiskâyiw . At last night came.
iyikohk mistah êh-tipiskâyik , êkwah sipwêhtêw ôw ôskinîkiw . When it was entirely dark, the youth set out.
namoya kiskêyihtam tântêh k-êsi-sipwêhtêt . He did not know in what direction he was going.
êyikohk mînah ê-wîh-wâpaniyik , itah ê-pasahcâyik , ê-sakâyik , êkotah mîna kawisimôw . When daylight was again near, again he lay down, in a wooded ravine.
sakâhk êkwa ôki mîna ntonikêwak ayîsiyiniwak ; mâka âsay wâhyaw ayâw aw oskinîkiw . Now, those people searched also in the woods; but by this time the youth was far away.
nâh-nôhtaw ohcih wayôniwak kâ-ntonawâcik . The searchers all turned back before they had come upon him.
kapê-kîsik nipâw aw ôskinîkiw . The young man slept all day.
iyikohk êh-otâkosik , êkoyikohk pêkopayiw . In the evening he awoke.
kîtahtawê kâ-pêhtahk ê-matwê-mâtôwiht . Presently he heard someone weeping.

êkwah ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamât kâ-mâtôyit , kâ-nisitawêyimât ostêsah , êkotah êh-ispatinâyik êh-na-nîpawiyit . When he made to see the one who was weeping, he recognized his brother, standing motionless on a hill.
êkosih âhci pikoh kâsôhtawêw . So he kept hiding from him.
wiy ohci k-ôh-mâtôyit , êh-wanihikot . His brother was weeping for him, because he had lost him.

piyisk ê-wîh-tipiskâyik , aspin êh-kîwêyit , iyikohk êkây êh-pêhtawât , wîst êkwa sipwêhtêw , êh-tipiskâyik . At last, as darkness was coming on, his brother departed to go home; when he heard him no more, he, too, set out, in the dark.
êyako mîna kapê-tipisk pimohtêw . All of that night again he walked.

êyikoyk ê-wîh-wâpaniyik , kont îtah kawisimôw ,
misawâc wâhyaw ntayân êkwah , êy-itêyihtahk ; Toward daybreak, he lay down, wherever he happened to be, thinking, “Now I am surely far off;
misawâc namoy âwiyak nka-wâpamik , êh-itêyihtahk . now surely no one will see me.”
iyikohk êh-pêkopayit , âsay spi-kîsikâyiw . When he awoke, it was already bright day.
kiyâm êh-kîsikâk êkwa nika-pimohtân , itêyihtam . “I may as well walk by daylight now,” he thought.
tâpwêh sipwêhtêw . So he started off.
nama wîhkâc mîcisôw , aspin kâ-sipwêhtêt . He had not eaten from the time he set out.
kapê-kîsik êh-pimohtêt , iyikohk êh-ati-tipiskâyik , mîna kont îtah kawisimôw . He walked all day, and when darkness was falling, again lay down where he happened to be.
âsay nôhtêhkatêw . By this time he was hungry.
mîna êh-wâpaniyik , âsay mîna sipwêhtêw . The next morning he went on.
namoya mâka kiskêyihtam tântêh t-êtohtêt . He did not know, however, where he was going.
nama wîhkâc kîh-papâh-wâpahtam ôm âskiy . He had never gone about seeing the world.
êkosi mistahi nôhtêhkatêw . He was very hungry now.
nama wîhkâc êh-tipiskâyik êkwah pimohtêw , pikw êh-kîsikâyik . Now he never walked at night, but only in daytime.
piyisk êtokê wâhyaw êkwah ayâw , wiya tahto-kîsikâw êh-pimohtêt . In time he must have gone very far, walking every day, as he did.
kîtahtawê kiskêyihtam êh-yîkicikâwit , êkw ês ânih mistah êh-kawâhkatosot . Presently he felt himself growing feeble; indeed, he was almost prostrate with hunger.
nama wîhkâc ayisk mîcisôw , ohcitaw êkâ ê-wîh-nipahât kêkway ta-mîcit . For he never ate, purposely refraining from killing anything he might eat.

seg.gloss: “Oh, it really looks as if I should simply starve to death.
It would be better if some creature should kill me.

p.seg: mîna êkâ kêkway nipahikoyâni , niya kîkway ahpôh nipahtâyâni , mîna kotak kêkway miskamâni ta-kîh-âpacihtâyân , nikah-kîwân , nânitaw ohtinamân , êh-itêyihtahk ; But if nothing kills me, and if I, by any chance, kill something, and if, besides, I find something that I can use, then I shall go home, if from any place I get something,” he thought;
ncawâc êkwah kêkway wâpahtamâni ta-kîh-mîciyân , nka-kakwê-nipahtân , itêyihtam . “If I see anything I can eat, I suppose I had better try to kill it,” he thought.
mâka nama kêkway kîh-wâpahtam . But he did not see anything.

kîtahtawê êkwah namoya kîh-mîhkawikiw , osâm êh-kawâhkatisot , pikoh mistik ohci ê-saskahohtêt , êh-nisôwâhkatosot êkwah . Then in time he could no longer walk with any speed, so weak was he from hunger; he hobbled along leaning on a stick, feeble from starvation.

kîtahtawê nîswâw ê-kîh-nipât , êkoyikohk kâ-wâpamât pihyêwa ,
nka-kakwê-nipahâw , êkwah kê-mîcisoyân , êh-itêyihtahk . Presently, after two nights, at last he saw a partridge, and thought, “I shall try to kill it, that I may eat.”
tâpwê pimwêw ; nipahêw . So he shot an arrow at it; he killed it.
otinêw êkwah , ê-pa-paskopitât . He took it and plucked off the feathers.
kisiwâk ôtah ispatinâyiw ; awasitah wâpahtam ê-sakâyik . Near by was a rise in the land; he saw that there was a wood beyond.
êkotah nka-kakwê-kapêsin , itêyihtam , ê-sipwêhtêt . “I shall try to camp there for the night,” he thought and set out.
êh-ati-sâkêwêt , kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhpis êh-cimatêyik . When he got to the top of the hill, he saw a little lodge standing there.
tâpwêh nimiywêyihtên ayîsiyiniwak ta-wâpamakik , itêyihtam . “Truly, I am glad that I shall see some people,” he thought.
namwâc mâ-mitonêyihtam ta-misi-wanâcihikot , He did not consider that they might destroy him;
iyâyaw êkwah kê-pimâtisiyân ; niwîh-nipahâhkatosoh , êh-itêyihtahk . “Now I am surely destined to live; otherwise I should have died of hunger,” he thought.
itohtêw êkotah . He went there.

êh-takohtêt , nama kêkway wâpahtam wayawîtimihk , kâ-matwê-pîkiskwêwiht ,
ta-tawâw , nôsisimis ! pîhtokâ ! kâ-matwêhitwêyit nôtokêsiwa . When he reached the place, he saw nothing outside the lodge, but someone spoke for him to hear, “Come in, grandchild! Come right in!” said an old woman, for him to hear.
êh-pîhtokêt , awîn ôhi kîh-pêyakoyiwa . When he entered, why, there she was, all alone.

nôsisimis , nôsisimis , êh-itikot ,
mânih êh-âyimaniyik têh k-êtohtêt ! k-êtikot ; “My grandchild, my grandchild,” she said to him; “Heavens, it is a dangerous place whether he is bound!” she told him;
nêtê ohc-âpih , itik . “Sit down over there,” she told him.
êkwah miyêw ôhi pihêwah . Then he gave her that partridge.
nôhkô , awa môwâhkan , itêw . “Grandmother, take this to eat,” he told her.
tâpwê , nôsisimis êh-atamihit ! itik ; “Truly, my grandchild is giving me a treat!” she said to him;

seg.gloss: “And so my grandchild has been going hungry!

p.seg: nika-paminawatâw , itik . I shall cook something for him,” she said to him.

êh-apisîsisiyit askihkosah k-âkotâyit , êkwa nîso êh-apisâsiniyikih wiyâsisah êh-pakastawêhamiyit , nîso mîna mênisisah , After hanging up a tiny little kettle, she put into the water two tiny bits of meat and two little berries;

ninôhtêhkatâh , apisîs kâ-pakâhtâkohkêt nôhkom ! itêyihtam . “Here am I, starving, and my grandmother puts so little food in her kettle!” he thought. LB on {kâ-pakâhtâkohkêt}: One would expect a different formation, but the word is common: {pakâhtâkuhkâw}: “he sets food to boil.”

êkos ômis îtik :
nôsisê , âyiman itêh k-êtohtêyin . At once she said to him, “Grandchild, it is an evil place to which you are going.

seg.q: namoya wîhkâc pê-kîwêw awiyak , êkotê êtohtêcih .
seg.gloss: Never does anyone return, when people go there.

p.seg: âta mâna nikitahamawâwak oskinîkiwak , itwêyiwa ; In vain do I always try to dissuade the young men,” she said;

seg.gloss: “Grandson, you had better go back home in the morning.

p.seg: âyiman ôma têh k-êtohtêyan , itik . It is an evil place to which you are going,” she told him.

seg.q: yahâ , nôhkô , osâm âsay wâhyaw nitayân .
seg.gloss: “Oh, grandmother, I am too far along by now.

seg.q: ahpôh ôma kontah kê-nipahâhkatosoyân , mâka wiya êkotê takohtêyâni , misi-wanâcihikoyâni kîkwayah , ta-miywâsin .
seg.gloss: As it is, I shall die of hunger, to no purpose; if I reach that place and something or other destroys me, it will be as well.

p.seg: ispîhcih kontah ta-nipahâhkatosoyân , namoya nka-kîh-kîwân , itêw . If to no purpose I starve to death on the way, then too I shall not reach home,” he told her.

hâw , nôsisimis , nêwotipiskwah ôtah ayâh , mâka ka-kiskinôhamâtân kîkway , tânsi tit-âyîhtiyan , itik . “Very well, my grandchild, stay here four nights, and I shall at any rate teach you something as to the way you shall do,” she told him. CHECK nêwotipiskwah, seems to be based on a noun, tipiskw-

seg.gloss: “Yes!”

p.seg: êkoyikohk êkwah êh-asamikot ; êkwah ma-mîcisôw . Then she gave him food; he ate.
namoya kîh-kitâw ôh iyikohk k-âsamikot . He was not able to eat up those things which she gave him to eat.
êkây ê-kîh-kitât , itisinamawêw ôhkomah . When he could not eat them all, he handed them to his grandmother. Should êkây be êkâ?
nêy ! tâpwê yîkicikâwiw êh-mîcisot nôsisim ! itik . “Goodness me! Truly my grandson is a poor eater!” she said to him.

êkwah êh-kakêskimikot , ôm îtêh kâ-wîh-itohtêt , êyakoh ê-wîhtamâkot , piyisk êkwah ê-nikamohikot . Then she instructed him about the place to which he was going, telling him about it, and finally teaching him songs.

kîtahtawêh ômis îtik :
nôsisê , kinêstosinôtokê ! Presently she said to him, “Grandson, you must be tired!
kiyâm pitah nipâh , itik . You had better sleep now,” she told him.
êkosi kawisimôw . And so he went to bed.

iyikohk êh-pêkopayit ,
nôsisê , waniskây êkwa ! mîcisoh ! nikîsi-paminawason , itwêyiwa . When he awoke, “Grandson, get up now! Eat! I have finished cooking,” she said.
êkwah waniskâw . Then he arose.
êkosi êh-pê-pakitinamâkot ôh ôtaskihkosiyiwa , êkwah êh-mîcisot . Then she brought her tiny kettle and set it before him, and he ate.

piyisk kîspôw ,
tâpwê âh-apisîs mîcisôw nôsisimis ! êh-itikot . After a while he had enough, and, “Truly, little at a time does my grandchild eat!” she told him.
êkoyikohk nôhkô , êh-kîspoyân mâna , itêw . “When I have as much as this, I am always filled,” he told her.
êkosi kapê-kîsik êkotah ay-ayâw . Then he stayed there all day, for several days.

wêtâkosiniyikih , kâh-mîcisotwâwi , êkos êh-nikamohikot , iyikohk êhkêyimikocih ,
kawisimoh ! êh-itikot . In the evening, when they had eaten, she would teach him songs, and when she thought he had enough of it, she would say to him, “Go to bed!”

ê-kîh-nêyo-tipiskâyik ,
hâw , êkwah , nôsisê , êkwah ka-sipwêhtêyan , itik . When the fourth night had come, “Now them, my grandson, the time has come for you to go,” she told him.

âsay nêma kâ-kiy-isi-miywamahcihot , sayâw nêwotipiskwah êh-asamikot ôhkomah , âsay miton tâhcipôw ; By this time he felt in good health again, when for four nights his grandmother had fed him; he was quite stout by this time; LB on {sayâw}: Unfamiliar particle; perhaps wrongly recorded.
namoy êkwah kawâhkatosôw . he no longer was feeble from starvation.

ômis îtik ôhkomah :
nôsisê , ât ôma êkos ê-isi-kiskinôhamawakik oskinîkiwak , mâka namoya nitâpwêhtâkok , k-ô-mâh-misi-wanâtisicik . His grandmother told him as follows: “My grandson, even though I have taught young men in this same way, they did not follow my instructions, and therefore, went, one after another, to their ruin.

seg.gloss: If you heed my words, you will fare well;

p.seg: mâka sâkôcimiskih awa kâ-wîh-otihtat , ka-misi-wanâcihik , itik ; but if he dissuades you to whom you will come, he will destroy you,” she told him;

kêyiwêhk awa pimiwih , êh-itikot , êh-miyikot êmiskôhôsiwayânisah ; “At any rate, carry this on your person,” she told him, giving him the skin of a beaver-owl; LB on {êmiskôhôsiwayânisah}: Later in the story we have the transparent form {amisk-ôhôsiwayânis} pointing to a word *{amisk-ôhôw}: “beaver-owl,” but I dare not correct the present form, because vowel change in the initial syllable is archaic in Central Algonquian in several noun-formations.

seg.gloss: “This thing, my grandson, you will keep for four nights.

seg.q:
êkâ misi-wanâcihiskih , nôhtêhkwasiyini ,
nimosô , pita nika-pimisinin ! kik-êtâw .
seg.gloss: If he does not destroy you, when you are sleepy, ‘Grandfather, let me lie down a while!’ you will say to him.
If he says ‘Yes,’ you will place this thing on your chest.
‘Now then, if my grandfather speaks to you, answer him! I shall sleep.
When daylight is near, then wake me!’ you will say to this thing.

p.seg:
êkwah awa , itik ,
itâmihk kika-saniskamâson , itik , êh-miyikot otâsiyâniyiwa ôhkomah ; And this,” she told him, “You will spread under you as you lie,” his grandmother told him, as she gave him her breech-clout;

seg.q: êkos piko ka-kî-sâkôcihâw , tôtamanih , ana kisêyiniw .
seg.gloss: “Only by doing thus will you be able to overcome that old man.

seg.q: êkwah cîkih ihtâyanih , mistik kik-ât-ôtinên , namoya êh-misâk mistik , ôma kiy-âti-pimohtêyin .
seg.gloss: And when you are near there, as you go along you will pick up a stick, a stick that is not large.
seg.note: LB on {kiy-âti-pimohtêyin}: The {kiy-} is probably an error of record.

seg.gloss: When you have slept twice on the way, you will see water.

p.seg: namwâc kika-wâpahtên tântê êh-kisipâkamâk , itik ; Not at all will you be able to see where that body of water has its end,” she told him;

seg.q: êkosi pôn-âpihtâ-kîsikâki , êkoyikohk kisiwâk kik-ôtihtên anima sâkahikan .
seg.gloss: “And so, after the day is past noon, then you will have come near that lake.
It will be level land.
You will see a very small rise in the land.
To it you will go; there you will seat yourself.

seg.q: kî-nahapiyini , êkotah cîki sâkahikanihk ka-wâpamâw ta-pê-sâkêwêt ayîsiyiniw êh-misikitit .
seg.gloss: When you have seated yourself, there close to the lake you will see a tall man come into view.
He will be dressed like a woman.
You will not see his feet.

seg.q:
pê-takohtêci ,
hâ , nôsisê , kîwêh ! kâ-pê-nâtat kika-kîwêhtahâw , kik-êtik .
seg.gloss: When he comes to where you are, ‘Ha, grandson, go back home! The one you have come to fetch you may take home with you,’ he will say to you.
At that a handsome white horse will come forth into view.
‘There, this one I give to you.
Go home!’ he will say to you.
Do you not heed his words.

seg.q:
ômis îtâhkan :
namoya êyakoh kâ-ntawêyimak , kik-êtâw .
seg.gloss: Say this to him: ‘It is not this one I desire,’ you will say to him.

seg.q:
êkosi ,
yâh , tapwêh êkwah , nôsisê ! kik-êtik .
seg.gloss: Then, ‘Oh, yes, that is true, grandson!’ he will say to you.
He will take you back with him to the place from which he came.

seg.q: pê-nâtah aspapiwin , ohcitaw ta-kîwê-têhtapiyan , kik-êtik , takohtêyêkoh wîkihk ;
seg.gloss: ‘Go bring the saddle, that you may ride home,’ he will say to you, when you reach his dwelling;

seg.q: nôsisê , ntaw-ôtnah ! pîhtokê ! êh-mîkisiwik aspapiwin , kik-êtik .
seg.gloss: ‘Go, grandon, and take it! Go right in! It is a beaded saddle,’ he will tell you.

seg.q: otinamani , sakôcimiski , ta-pê-itohtêw anih ana misatim .
seg.gloss: If you take it, persuaded by his speech, that horse will indeed come there.
‘Take him; saddle him’ he will say to you.
When you have saddled him, ‘Mount!’ he will tell you;
‘Go home!’ he will tell you.

seg.q: sâkôcimiskih , têhtapiyini , wîh-âtah-sipwêhtêyini , iyâyaw sâkahikanihk kik-êsi-sipwêhtahik ana misatim .
seg.gloss: If he persuades you, and you mount, try as you may to depart, that horse will take you off straight to the lake.
You will not be able to manage him.
In the end he will go under the water.
You must wait for a different horse to come up from the water;

p.seg: êyakw âna ka-misi-wanâcihisk , itik ; that one will destroy you,” she told him;

seg.gloss: “Four nights you will stay there.

seg.q: kîspin tâpwêhtawiyini ôma k-êtitân , êkos âna ta-sâkôcihat , kîspin nêotipiskwah êkotah ayâyani .
seg.gloss: If you heed this which I tell you, you will overcome him, if you stay there four nights.

seg.q: mâka anima k-êspacinâsik nahapiyini , pêcâstamohtêcih , êk ânima tâpwêhtawaci ôma k-êtitân , ka-kîhkîhkimik .
seg.gloss: But when you are sitting on that little mound, and he comes walking to where you are, if them you do not heed this which I have told you, he will talk you into acting against your will.
‘Go ahead, walk right in!’ he will tell you.
‘Do you enter first!’ you will say to him.

seg.q: ispih sâkôcimacih , wîh-pîhtokêcih , ati-pîhtokêcih , ôm ôhci miscikos kik-ôhpâskwahamwân oskotâkay .
seg.gloss: If you persuade him, as he is about to go in, just as he enters the dwelling, with that little stick you will lift up his skirt.
You will see his feet.
You will see that his feet are like a horse's.

seg.q: wêy ! tânis âwa nimosôm êy-isinâkwaniyikih ositah ! kik-êtâw .
seg.gloss: ‘Heavens! What do my grandfather's feet look like!’ you will say to him.
‘What do they look like, grandson?
Do you mean to say that you see them?’ he will ask you.

seg.q: êhag ! tâpiskôc misatimoskasiyah êsinâkwahkih kisitah , kik-êtâw .
seg.gloss: ‘Yes! Your feet look like horses' hoofs,’ you will answer him.
My grandchild, be sure, by all means, to try to see his feet.
If you see them, then indeed you will overcome him.

p.seg: mâka êkâ wâpahtamani , kika-sâkôcihik , itik ; But if you do not see them, if you do not do as I now am teaching you, he will overcome you,” she told him;

seg.q: mâka wâpahtamani ositah , êkos âni ka-sâkôcihâw .
seg.gloss: “But if you see his feet, then indeed you will overcome him.

seg.q: êkwah êyako nêwotipiskwah kîh-ayâyanih , êkosi tahto-kîsikâw pêyak misatimwah kika-miyik .
seg.gloss: Then if you succeed in staying there four nights, then every day he will give you one horse.
‘Go home!’ he will tell you.
You will not obey him.

seg.q: âta wiy âni ôhcitaw sâkôcihacih , kika-miyik êwakoni misatimwah .
seg.gloss: It is really only if you defeat him that he will give you those horses.

seg.q:
kîh-nêo-tipiskâkih , êkotah ayâyini ,
hâ , nimosô , kitêm ana nâpêstim êyôkw âna kâ-pê-nâtak , kik-êtâw .
seg.gloss: When the fourth night of your stay has passed, ‘Now, grandfather, it is your own horse, the stallion, that I have come to fetch,’ you will say to him.
‘Very well,’ he will answer you.
By the door there will be lying an ugly saddle;
and the rawhide bridle, strung together of small ends, will be ugly.
For these you will ask him.

seg.q: ôhi kotakah ê-mâh-miywâsikih aspapiwinah , pîsâkanâpiyah , êwakoni , kik-êtik .
seg.gloss: ‘It is those other saddles that are good, and those bridles,’ he will say to you.
Do not heed his words.

p.seg: êkotah anim ôhci ta-sâkôcihisk , âta nêotipiskwah paspiyini , itik ; He will defeat you with this one thing, even though you go unharmed through the four nights,” she told him;

seg.q:
mîn êwako sâkôcimaci ,
hâw , êkwah , nôsisê , ntêm kâ-pê-nâtat , kik-êtik .
seg.gloss: “If you persuade him this time too, ‘Very well then, grandson; now for my own horse which you have come to fetch!’ he will say to you.
Then he will go out of the lodge.

seg.q: êyakw ânima kâ-mâyâtahk aspapiwin pîsâkanâpiy tit-ôtinam .
seg.gloss: He will take that very same ugly saddle and bridle.
Then you will follow him.
He will stand beside the lake.
‘My horse, come to land!’ he will call.

seg.q: kiyipah nipiy mistahi ta-cimatêw ; tâpiskôc êh-ohtêk t-êsinâkwan .
seg.gloss: At once the water will rise up high; it will look as if it were boiling.
At last a stallion with a bay coat will come out of the water.
It will come to the land.
It will drag its tail on the ground.
And its mane, here, too, will almost reach the ground.
When it comes to land, ‘There, grandson, take him!’ he will say to you.
Do not obey him.
‘Take him for me!’ you will say to him.
When he has taken it, ‘Saddle him for me!’ you will say to him.

seg.q:
wiyahpitâci , êkoyikohk êkwah ,
nah , nôsisê ! kik-êtik .
seg.gloss: When he has saddled it, then, ‘Here you are, grandson!’ he will say to you.
Do not heed his speech.
‘Put me on his back!’ do you then say to him.
If you do this, you will live; you will defeat him.

p.seg: mâka maywês têhtahiskih otinaci , kika-misi-wanâcihik êyokw âna misatim ; kika-môwik , itik ; But if you take the horse before he has set you on its back, that horse will destroy you; it will eat you,” she told him;

seg.gloss: “But if he puts you on its back, then indeed you will come home.

seg.q: nêwotipiskwah anima kiy-âyâyin , êkosi nê-mitanaw misatimwak ta-paskiyawat ana kisêyiniw .
seg.gloss: Having stayed there four nights, you will win forty horses from that old man.

seg.q: ât âni kêtimâkinawakwâwi oskinîkiwak , êkos ôma êsi-kiskinôhamawakik , mâka namoya nitâpwêhtâkwak .
seg.gloss: But though again and again I have taken pity on young men and instructed them even in this wise, yet they have not obeyed me.

p.seg: misahkamik oskinîkiwak êkâ k-ôh-pê-kîwêcik , êh-ati-misi-wanâcihikocik , itik ; That is why any number of young men have not returned from there, but have been destroyed by him,” she told him;

mistahi kaskêyihtam kôhtâwiy kikâwiy kistês kîtimwak aniki kâ-kitimâkêyimiskik , itik . “Very sad is your father, and your mother, and your elder brother, and those your sisters-in-law who are fond of you,” she told him.
êkwah sipwêhtêw êkwah , ê-kîh-miyikot ôhi kâ-wîh-miyikot . Then he set out, after she had given him the things she wished to give him.

kâ-sipwêhtêt ,
nîswâw kika-nipân , ka-kîh-itikot , nîswâw ê-kîh-nipât , êkoyikohk wâpahtam sâkahikan . When he set out, “Twice you will sleep on the way,” she had told him; and so, when twice he had slept, then he saw a lake.
namwâc têpâpahtam têh-kisipikamâyik . Not at all could he see to where the water had its end.
piyis cîk êkwah ay-ihtâw ôma sâkahikan . At last he came there, close to that lake.
piyis ê-pôn-âpihtâ-kîsikâk , ôma k-êspacinâsiyik wâpahtam . At last, when the day was past noon, he saw a small knoll.
êkotah nahapiw . There he sat down.
êh-âtay-itâpit , nama kêkway wâpahtam . Look as he might, he saw nothing.
piyisk kâ-pê-sâkêwêyit sâkahikanihk ohci ayîsiyiniwah , êh-pêh-itohtêyit . At last a person came into sight from the lake, and walked toward him.
tâpiskôc iskwêw , itêyimêw , êh-kinwâyik oskotâkayiw . “Just like a woman,” he thought of him, for his skirt was long.

êkosi ,
kîwêh , itik ,
nôsisê ! itik . Then, “Go home,” this person said to him, “My grandson!” he said to him.
hâ , namoya ! êh-pê-ntawâpamitân , itêw . “Oh no! The fact is I have come to visit you!” he answered him.

hâ , nôsisê , kâ-pê-nâtat ka-kîwêhtahâw ! êh-itikot , âsay ka-pêcâstamohtêyit , ê-pê-sâkêwêyit êh-wâpiskisiyit misatimwa . “Ha, grandson, the one you have come to fetch you shall take home with you!” the other told him, walking toward him; and at the same time a white horse came forth into view.

seg.gloss: “it is not this one I have come to fetch.
It is your own horse I have come to fetch!”

seg.q: yâ , êwako mâka ntêm ê-sâkihak kâ-miyitân !
seg.gloss: “Dear me, but this is my own horse that I prize very highly, which I am giving you!”

p.seg: namoya êwako ! itêw . “Not this one!” he answered him.
kah ! êkwah mâka oma k-ôhtohtêyân , êkotah itohtêh ! niyâ ! itik . “Oh, indeed?” Well, then go to the place where from which I have come! Go on!” the other told him.
namoya , nimosô ! kiya nîkânohtê ! itêw . “No, grandfather! Do you walk ahead!” he told him.
kîhkîhkimik . The other tried to talk him down.

piyisk , wîstah êh-kîhkîhkimât , piyis tâpwêhtâk , êkwah ê-sipwêhtêyit ,
hâ , nôsisê , ot êsi nawac pimohtê ! êh-itikot . At last, as he argued back, the other gave in to him and set out, saying to him, “Well, grandson, walk right ahead here!”
pimohtêwaki , ta-wâpahtam nisitah , êh-itêyimikot , êyakw ânima k-ôh-itikot . “If I walk before him, he will see my feet,” the other thought concerning him; that was why he said this to him.
êkos êh-ati-sâkêwêcik , awîn ôma , ki-misâyiw mîkiwâhp . So, when they went on and came to the other side of the knoll, there was a large tipi.

ê-takohtêcik ,
â , nôsisê , pîhtokê ! When they reached it, “There, grandson, go in!

seg.q: ôtê isi ka-wâpahtên aspapiwin êh-mîkisiwik , mîna pîsâkanâpiy êh-miywâsik , tit-ôtinaman , ci-t-âpacihtâyin ô ka-miyitân ntêm , ta-kîwêyan .
seg.gloss: Over on this side you will see a beaded saddle, and an excellent rawhide thong bridle, that you may take to use on this my horse which I shall give you, when you go home.”
“Oh, no! I do not mean to go home!

p.seg: kotak kitêm kâ-pê-nâtak ! itêw . It is another horse of yours which I have come to fetch!” he told him.

piyisk kîhkîhkimik ,
kiya nîkân pîhtokê ! êh-itikot . Then the other urged him by speech; “Do you go in first!” he told him.
wîstah kîhkîhkimêw . He, in turn, urged the other.
piyis mîna sâkôcimêw . In the end, again he persuaded the other.
wâpahtam êh-misatimositêyit . he saw that he had horses' feet.

êh-ati-pîhtokêt ,
tânisy âwa nimosôm êsisitêt ? itêw . As he entered, “What kind of feet has my grandfather?” he said to him.
nôsisê , ê-wâpahtaman cî nisitah ? itik . “Grandson, do you mean to say that you see my feet?” the other asked him.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”
“What do they look like?”
“You have feet just like a horse!”

p.seg: kah ! tâpw ês âni kiwâpahtên nisitah ! itik . “You don't say! So you really have seen my feet!” the other said to him.
êkosih ati-ta-tipiskâyiw . Then night came on.

êkwah êkotah êh-ayât , ispih mistahis êh-tipiskâyik ,
nôsisê , namoya ka-nipânânaw , kik-ây-âcimoyahk , itik . Then, as he stayed there, when it had grown fairly dark, “Grandson, let us not sleep, but tell stories,” the other said to him.
êhag ! pita nka-wayawîn , itêw omosôma . “Very well! First let me go outside a moment,” he said to his grandfather.
êkosi wayawîw . Accordingly, he went outside.

êkwah ôhkomah otâsiyâniyiwa itâmihk ôtê ê-sakaniskamâsot , êkwah anihi amisk-ôhôsiwayânisah êyakonih wâskikanihk sêkoyahkinêw . Then he fastened on his grandmother's breech-clout down below here, and that skin of a beaver-owl he slipped between his garments on his chest.
pîhtokêw êkwah . Then he entered the lodge.
êkosi êkwah apiw . So then he sat there.

êkwah ,
êkwah âcimoy ! itik . Then, “Now tell a tale!” the other said to him.
êkwah ay-âcimôw . Then he told stories.
namoya âcimêw anihi nôtokêsiwa . he did not tell about the old woman.
piyisk oma k-êsi-wâpamât êyôkw âcimôw . He told the story up to the point where he saw the other.
piyisk pôn-âcimôw . At last he finished his tale.

êkosi ,
êkwah niyay ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw , êkwah êh-âcimot . At that, “My turn now!” said the old man, and began to narrate.

kapê-tipisk êkwah êyakw âcimôw ,
hêhag ! êh-itât mâna aw ôskinîkiw . All night long he told tales, the youth saying, “Yes!” from time to time.
piyisk nôhtêhkwasiw . At last he grew sleepy.
nimosô , nika-pa-pimisinin ! êkosi k-êsi-nitohtâtân ! itêw . “Grandfather, let me lie down! Let me listen to you that way!” he asked him.
êhag ! - nipâcih , ayis ta-nipahikot ôhi kisêyiniwa . “Very well!” for if he slept, the old man would kill him.
êkosi êkwah pimisin . So now he lay down.
hâw , itêw ôhi ôtah kâ-sêkoyahkinât ; “Now then,” he said to that thing which he had between his garments here;

ômis îtêw :
nnôhtêhkwasin ! niwîh-nipân ! this he said to it: “I am sleepy! I want to sleep!

seg.gloss: Speak to this old man whenever he speaks to you!

p.seg: wîh-wâpahkih , koskonihkan ! itêw . When dawn is at hand, then wake me!” he told it.

seg.gloss: “Yes!”

p.seg: êkosi êkwah êh-nipât wiya . So now he went to sleep.

êkwah awa kisêyiniw êh-ay-âcimot ,
nôsisê ! êtâcih ,
wêy ! êh-itikot ôhi amisk-ôhôsiwayânisah ,
âta wiya cî kimiyohtawin ?
êhag ! êh-itikot . And as the old man went on which his stories, whenever he said to him, “Grandson!” that beaver-owl skin would answer, “Yes, I hear!” and to his, “You are following my story, are you?” the other would answer “Yes!”

seg.gloss: “Now then, my grandson, you have come from afar.
Only once will you sleep on the way.
There where you sleep, horses now will overtake you.
I prize very highly this one I have given you.
When you arrive off yonder in your people's home, then make me an offering of stewed beries.

These are my instructions to you, my grandson.
You will ask for many strands of incense grass, that you may burn incense to the horses.
You will have them go about with the strands of incense grass in their mouths.
Your kinsmen will help you put the grass into the horses' mouths.

êyakoni aw ôstêsimâw nka-miyâw , êy-itêyihtahk , wiya pik ôhi nâpêstimwah êh-ayâwât . He kept out one poor one, thinking, “This I shall give to that brother of mine,” and for himself he kept only that stallion.
êkosi êkoyikohk . So much for this.

êkwah pîhtêyisk êkwah ntayi-mânokêwân ôma mîkiwâhp , êkwah êh-miyikot ôhtâwiyah tit-ôkimâwit , ta-tipêyimât kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwa . Then the people went and set up that tent for him in the centre of the camp, and his father gave him the chieftaincy, that he might rule over all the people.
êh-wâpaniyik , êkwah kâ-ntomât ostêsah wîwiyiwah kikih , ôhi kâ-kîh-tahkamikot . In the morning then he summoned his elder brother, the one who had stabbed him, together with his wife.

êkwah êh-pîhtokêyit ,
â , tawâw ! itêw ; As they entered, “Oh, come in!” he said to them;
â , kontah ê-cîsimitân ! itêw ostêsah . “Oh, I am merely putting you to needless trouble!” he said to his elder brother.

ê-wîh-atamiskâkot ôhi wîtimwa , namoya tâpwêhtawêw . When his sister-in-law would greet him, he paid no attention to her. LB on {ê-wîh-atamiskâkot}: In ordinary use this word implies shaking hands; I do not know whether this is always the case.

ômis îtêw ostêsah :
ê-wîh-kakwêcimitân , itêw . He said to his brother, “The fact is that I want to ask you something,” he told him.
êhag ! kakwêcimin , nisîm , itik . “Very well, ask me, brother,” the other answered him.

seg.q:
tânêhki ,
nikitimâkêyimik , ê-kîh-itêyimitân , anima ka-kîh-tôtawiyin , kêkâc kâ-nipahiyan ?
seg.gloss: “Why, when I thought of you, ‘He loves me,’ did you do that to me, when you nearly killed me?

p.seg: kêkway ohci ? itêw . What was the reason?” he asked him.
ncawâc nôhtê-wayawîw aw îskwêw . That woman saw nothing to do but go out of the tent.
ya , êkâ wiyah ! itêw awa owîkimâkana ; “Ho, do not!” said that man to his wife;

seg.gloss: “Do not go out!

p.seg: pitah ta-kîsâcimôw nisîm , itêw . First let my brother finish what he has to say,” he told her.

êh-kîsi-kakwêcimikot ,
hâ , nsîm , tâpwê kikîh-kitimâkêyimitin ; When the other had finished asking him, “Now, brother, I really did love you;

seg.gloss: and your sister-in-law here also loved you.
I was glad that your sister-in-law took such good care of you.

seg.q: naspâc k-êtêyihtaman ; êh-pêyakwapiyân , êh-pîhtokêt kisîm , kâ-kakwêcimit êh-wîh-nôcîhkawit , ntik .
seg.gloss: ‘You were badly mistaken; when I was alone in the tent your young brother came in [no translation]’ she told me.

p.seg:
êkwah nikisiwâsin ,
tâpwê kakêpâtisiw ! êh-itêyimitân , mistah êh-kitimâkêyimitâhk , itik . Then I was angry, and ‘Truly, his character is bad!’ I thought of you, seeing how much we had loved you!” he told him.

seg.q: wah , namoya , nistêsê ! nikiskêyihtên iyikohk ê-kîh-kitimâkêyimiyêk .
seg.gloss: “Dear me, no, brother! I know how much you loved me.

seg.q: tâpwê êy-itohtêyân , kîkiwâhk êh-pîhtokêyân , pêyakwapiw kiwîkimâkan .
seg.gloss: It is true that when I came and entered your tipi your wife was sitting alone.
When I wanted to go out again, ‘First eat,’ she told me.
‘No, you are alone in the tent,’ I said to her.

q.q: nâ , namoya nântaw ê-pêyakwapiyân , iyikohk êh-kitimâkêyimitâhk .

seg.gloss: ‘Oh, it does not matter that I am alone, seeing how fond we are of you.’
So I sat down and she gave me food.
When I had eaten, and was rising to my feet, ‘First let me comb your hair,’ she said to me.
‘No, you are alone in the tent,’ I said to her.
When I tried to go out, she blocked me in the doorway.
[no translation] she said to me;
‘If you do as I ask, much as I have loved you, I shall take even better care of you.’
‘Why, how could I do such a thing?
My brother is so good to me,’ I said to her.
‘He does not need to know of it,’ she answered me.
Then, when she stepped aside, I came out.

p.seg: nnêpêwisin , tâpiskôc nikâwiy êh-itêyimakik kahkiyaw nîtimwak , iyikohk êh-kitimâkêyimicik , itêw ; I was embarrassed, for I looked upon all my sisters-in-law even as upon my mother, when they were so good to me,” he told him;

seg.q: êyakô ohci kinwêsk êkâ k-ôh-kîh-pîhtokêyân kîkiwâhk , ê-kîh-nêpêwihit awa k-âpit .
seg.gloss: “It was for this reason that for a long time I did not come into your tent, because she who sits here had put me to shame.

seg.q:
hâh , êkosi êwako kâ-wîh-kiskêyihtamân ,
tânêhki k-ô-kêh-tôtawit ? êh-itêyimitân .
seg.gloss: Well, this is what I wanted to know, for, ‘Why has he done this to me?’ was my thought concerning you.

p.seg: hâw , awa ôtah kâ-sakâhpisot kîwêhtah , êh-miyitân , itêw . Now then, take home with you the animal that is tethered here; I give him to you,” he told him.
hay hay ! itwêw aw ôstêsimâw . “Thanks, thanks!” said the elder brother.
mâka kisiwâsiw . But he was angry.
niyâ , kîwêtân ! itêw owîkimâkana . “Come, let us go home!” he said to his wife.

êh-ati-wayawîcik , nêt ê-takohtêcik wîkiwâhk , ê-kîh-sakâhpitât awa misatimwah , êkwah itêw owîkimâkana ,
sâkêwêtân oma k-êspatinâk , itêw . When they had gone out, as they came to their tent yonder, after tying up the horse, he said to his wife, “Let us go over that hill there.”

êkotah ê-kîh-nahapicik ,
mistah êcik ôma êh-kakêpâtisiyin ! When they had sat down there, “And so it appears that you are of a most evil nature!

seg.gloss: It appears that you were the one who had that desire!
Remember, I loved my little brother!

p.seg: kêkâc kâ-kêh-nipahtwâsoyân ! itêw , môhkomân êh-otinahk , êh-tah-tahkamât , êh-nipahât owîkimâkana . And here I came near killing what was dear to me!” he said to her, and taking a knife, stabbed her repeatedly, and killed her.
êkosi kîwêw . Then he went home.

êkwah awa aw ôskinîkiw ôhi wîtimwah , kâ-kîh-ntotamawât pahkêkinos oskinîkiskwêwa , êwakonih êkwah miyik ostêsah owîkimâkaniyiwa . Then that youth was given his sister-in-law, the young woman whom he had asked for a piece of leather; his elder brother, her husband, gave her to him.
êkonih êkwah wîwiw wîtimwa . So he had this sister-in-law of his to wife.
êkotah ohci aspin k-âskiwîk êkwêyâk misatimwak êkotah k-ôh-ôhpikicik . In this way, then, horses came to be, for the first time since the beginning of the world.

êkosi êkwah êy-iskwâk âtayôhkêwin , âcimowin . This, now, is the end of the sacred story, of the story. LB on {âcimowin}: After using the right word, informant corrects himself, substituting the wrong one.
